notes: Composed of chains made up of single bonds.
A straight and ordered orientation, packed tightly.

types.title: Lauric Acid
points: Coconut oil
Body doesn't change MCTs into body fat as easily, so it makes it less likely for MCTs to be stored in body and more likely to be burned for energy.
Increases total cholesterol levels, increasing HDL (high-density lipoprotein), the good cholesterol.

types.title: Stearic Acid
points: Milk, butter
Long-chain saturated fat.
Digestion-slowing properties. Keeps you fuller longer and flattens belly.
Regulates performance of mitochondria (which is the energy-producing powerhouse of the cell)
Lowers LDL cholesterol and inflammation in comparison to other fats.

types.title: Palmitic Acid
points: Palm oil, conventionally raised animal fats
Excess carbs are converted into palmitic acid.
Increases LDL (low-density lipoprotein)

notes: Composed of chains with a single double bond.
Cis formation. Chain before the double bound and after are on the same side.

types.title: Omega-9s / Oleic acid
points: Olive oil, walnuts, avocadoes
Can reduce appetite and promote weight loss
Raises HDL without raising LDL

notes: Essential fatty acids, we need them to thrive, but we can only get them by eating it.
Made up of chains with two or more double bonds.

types.title: Omega-3 fatty acids
points: 3 are essential to humans
ALA (alpha-linolenic acid), DHA (docosahexaenoic), EPA (eicosapentaenoic acid)
Reducing inflammation, cholesterol levels, body fat, and hunger.

types.title: Omega-6 fatty acids
points: Too much of Linoleic acid can lead to inflammation, overeating, weight gain, and heart disease.
Arachidonic acid increases lean body mass, strength, and anaerobic power.

notes: Trans orientation. Two different directions at the kink of the double bond.

types.title: Conjugated Linoleic Acid
points: Grass-fed beef, grass-fed dairy, turkey, lamb, veal
Produced in guts of cows, turkeys, and lamb.
Powerful antioxidant.

types.title: Partially Hydrogenated Oils
points: Fried foods, baked foods, margarine
Partially hydrogenating means to inject vegetable oil with hydrogen.
It turns oil solid even at room temperature when you do that.
They also turn solid when inside your body. Jamming up arteries, even the ones in your brain.
Increases risk of heart disease (increasing LDL and decreasing HDL), weight gain, diminishing memory

types.title: Vaccenic Acid
points: Grass-fed beef, grass-fed dairy, turkey, lamb, veal
